Authors:
Andre Wilson Campos Rosado, Isaias Severino Cacique, Danilo
Oliveira Ramos, Fábio Alex Custódio, Laércio Zambolim, Olinto Liparini
Pereira
Title:
Colletotrichum karsti causing fruit anthracnose on tamarillo
(Solanum betaceum) in Brazil
Abstract:
Tamarillo, also known as the tree tomato, is a plant that
belongs to the Solanaceae family. Tamarillo is a crop of relevance in
South America. Several Colletotrichum species have been reported causing
anthracnose on tamarillo from Colombia, however not yet in Brazil.
Tamarillo fruits showing anthracnose disease were observed in Viçosa,
Minas Gerais state, Brazil. This study aimed to determine the causal
agent of this disease, using sequence‑based phylogeny, colony
characterization, and morphology analyses. The rDNA-ITS, actin,
beta-tubulin, chitin synthase 1, Glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate
dehydrogenase, and histone loci were amplified by PCR. PCR products were
purified and sequenced. The phylogenetic analyses revealed that the
isolates of this study belong to the Colletotrichum boninense species
complex, i.e., Colletotrichum karsti. As far as we know, this is the
first report of C. karsti causing fruit anthracnose on tamarillo in
Brazil. This study contributes to the knowledge about the etiology of
fruit anthracnose on tamarillo in Brazil.
